sentences.text: Add OK or FAIL after other browsers where you have tested this issue:
What steps will reproduce the problem?
2.see the security error complaning about revoked ssl cert
Please provide any additional information below.
Could you give us more detailed information of your system?
Does it happens on linux version only?

Linux pedersen-dell 2.6.26-2-686 #1 SMP Thu Mar 26 01:08:11 UTC 2009 i686 GNU/Linux
KDE 4.2.2

I've tested this on my laptop as well, same error (same distro and DE) and I get the
same error there.
I've just tested 17726 and its still there.
I do not have the possibility to test this on another OS, I only use Linux.
Magnus: thanks for the system info.
You don't need to test this on another OS.
We suspect this is caused by the changelist at http://codereview.chromium.org/115913.
We just switched to the new NSS function CERT_PKIXCertVerify for verifying certificates.
Could you run these commands to get the version of NSS?

ii  libnss3-1d                          3.12.3-1                      Network 
Security Service libraries

ident error: /usr/lib32/libnss3.so: No such file or directory
(I'm not running 64 bit)
magnus: thanks for the NSS version info.

NSS 3.12.3 is the latest
NSS release, newer than the NSS 3.12.0 in Ubuntu 8.04, which most
of the Chromium developers are using.
Are you the same person who reported this problem in

ukai: if we can't track this down in two or three days, let's
reimplement X509Certificate::Verify using the old NSS function
CERT_VerifyCert instead of CERT_PKIXVerifyCert as a temporary
workaround.
Hi, I have the same bug.
It was me that reported this problem in codereview.
With NSS 3.12.3, I reproduced this bug.

All certificates are shown
as revoked.

So this bug is caused by some
change between NSS 3.12.2 and 3.12.3.

But the root cause is that
we haven't set up CRL and OCSP properly, and we're passing overly
strict revocation flags to CERT_PKIXVerifyCert for normal certificate
verification that says "consider the certificate revoked if we don't
have revocation info".

While that is appropriate for EV certificate
verification, we need to be more lenient for normal certificate
verification.
I have written a fix and should be able to check it in today.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Don't consider a certificate revoked if we don't have
fresh revocation status of the certificate.
We haven't written the code for NSS to use our network
stack to download CRLs or talk to OCSP responders, so NSS
TEST=none (requires a Linux system with NSS 3.12.3)
syscoder, magnus: please let me know if my checkin r17756 fixes this bug for you.
I just tried r17779 and it works.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
yup, works now, with 17826, great work :-)
Has there been a regression here?

Just installed nightly on kubuntu and am getting 
behavior similar to what was reported here, but not all certs cause failure.

gmail 
cert is accepted, for example.

en-US) AppleWebKit/532.0 (KHTML, 
like Gecko) Chrome/3.0.198.0 Safari/532.0
I'm also seeing it on Ubuntu Netbook Remix
converter42,bill.bacher: thanks for the bug report.
I bet this regression is introduced by ukai's checkin
I will come up with a fix and follow up in  issue 10911 .
The following revision refers to this bug:
Use strict revocation flags only for EV verification.
should not say the cert is revoked.
I'm with the same issue as reported above, but running on build 26151.

Testing with mastercard's site refered above, it works alright, but I can't access
any google page through https.

Running google-chrome-unstable on two Debian unstable machines- one is 32-bit and one 
is 64-bit.
Both are running NSS 3.12.3.1 and google-chrome-unstable 4.0.211.2-r26474.
32-bit can browse https:// sites with no problem.

caioromao,aaron.toponce: could you please check the system time on
the computer experiencing this problem?

Is the system time wrong
by any chance?
aaron.toponce: is this the place to download Debian unstable?
It uses NTP to adjust the clock.
I didn't use the development installer.

I used the stable installer to 
install this machine, and chose expert installation mode.

During installation, you'll 
be asked which release you want to install.
wtchang: now that you said it - it may have been wrong.

It started working for me when 
I was connected through another place and I remember adjusting the clock once.

I'll 
test it as soon as possible.
(I am the same person who posted comment 21.)

id=515279,
if the computer's system clock is wrong, Chrome may incorrectly report
certificates as revoked.

My experiments showed that the system clock
needs to be off by as much as 24 hours.

For example, if I turn the
system clock backward (into the past) by 24 hours, Chrome reports some
certificates as revoked.

If I turn the system clock backward (into the
past) by 48 hours, Chrome reports almost all certificates as revoked.

I filed issue 22796 for the "certificate revoked" errors caused
by an incorrect system time.

I suspect the problems reported
by caioromao and aaron.toponce are caused by incorrect system
times.

aaron.toponce says he's using NTP to adjust the clock,
so I don't know what the cause for his problem is.

aaron.toponce, if you are still seeing the "certificate revoked"
errors, and your system time is correct (please doublecheck the
time zone setting), please file a new bug report.

report is for "certificate revoked" errors caused by our passing
strict revocation flags to the CERT_PKIXVerifyCert function.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
I'm now affected by this bug.

It may or may not be related to the updates in my
system --the invalid certificate issue came up after I did my updates from Arch
Linux.
I think the system time is correct ($ date output: "Fri Jan  8 23:48:00 EST 2010").

I
also tried to downgrade ca-certificates and tzdata packages (did not reboot, does
that matter?)

The culprit might be one of the following but obviously it was not an nss upgrade
that did this in my case.
Should I open a new report?

run-parts-3.2.2-1  ca-certificates-20090814-2  kernel26-firmware-2.6.32.3-1
kernel26-2.6.32.3-1  kernel26-headers-2.6.32.3-1  libldap-2.4.21-1  perl-uri-1.52-1
zlib-1.2.3.4-3  util-linux-ng-2.16.2-1
Got fixed by itself without me doing any updates on my computer.

Although I'm glad your problem is
gone, it's too bad that we don't know what was wrong before.
Based on the time I received your comment 28 by email (at

Fri, Jan 8, 2010 at 9:53 PM US Pacific Standard Time), your system
time is correct or off by at most one hour, which should not be large
enough to trigger the NSS bug.

If this problem comes back, please open
a bug report and mention whether all certificates are revoked or just
certain certificates are revoked (give example URLs in that case).

title: All SSL certificates revoked on systems with NSS 3.12.3
